snippet: A senior aid official in Pakistan said the staff members of Save the Children had been given until Sept. 12 to leave the country, but hours later the interior minister issued a temporary reprieve.
abstract: Pakistani government appears to have moved to expel international staff members at the aid agency Save the Children, but later issues a temporary reprieve; original order was apparently due to accusations that one of its employees helped the Central Intelligence Agency recruit Shakil Afridi, a Pakistani doctor who played a role in tracking Osama bin Laden in 2011.

byline.contributor: Ismail Khan contributed reporting from Peshawar, Pakistan, Salman Masood from Islamabad, and Scott Shane from Washington.

lead_paragraph: A senior aid official in Pakistan said the staff members of Save the Children had been given until Sept. 12 to leave the country, but hours later the interior minister issued a temporary reprieve.

headline.seo: Pakistan Seems to Take Steps to Expel Foreign Staff Members of Save the Children
headline.main: Pakistan May Be Expelling Aid Group’s Foreign Staff
headline.print_headline: Pakistan May Be Expelling Aid Group’s Foreign Staff
